verses.text: A wise woman builds her house, but a foolish one tears it down with her own hands.
verses.comment: This verse uses the imagery of the household to symbolize the importance of wisdom in nurturing and protecting God's gifts. The theme of building up with virtue echoes the role of the Church as a spiritual household (1 Tim. 3:15).

verses.text: Whoever walks uprightly fears the Lord, but one who is devious in his ways despises Him.
verses.comment: Reverent fear of God is the foundation for righteousness. 'Walking uprightly' is both inward devotion and outward practice, reflecting a wholeness seen in lives of saints.

verses.text: In a fool’s mouth is a rod for his back, but the lips of the wise protect them.
verses.comment: Words can bring suffering or shelter. The 'rod' suggests self-inflicted punishment, reminding us that unwise speech leads to ruin, but wisdom aligns with the peace the Spirit gives (Gal. 5:22).

verses.text: Where there are no oxen, the manger is clean, but abundant crops come by the strength of an ox.
verses.comment: This proverb teaches that fruitfulness requires effort and sometimes disorder. The Christian life involves daily labor, not sterile perfectionism, echoing the parable of the talents (Matt. 25:14-30).

verses.text: A faithful witness does not lie, but a false witness breathes out lies.
verses.comment: Truthfulness is at the heart of God's law. This points to Christ as the True Witness (Rev. 1:5), and the Church as the pillar of truth.

verses.text: A scoffer seeks wisdom but finds none, but knowledge is easy for one who understands.
verses.comment: Hard-heartedness blocks spiritual sight. Those open to God receive wisdom gracefully, in a manner reminiscent of how spiritual truths are revealed to the simple and humble (Matt. 11:25).

verses.text: Leave the presence of a fool, for you do not find knowledge on his lips.
verses.comment: Discerning spiritual company is vital. Just as the early Church separated themselves from error, so too believers should cling to wisdom.

verses.text: The wisdom of the prudent is to understand his way, but the folly of fools is deception.
verses.comment: True wisdom means self-examination and honesty before God; this virtue is central to a well-ordered spiritual life. Compare the tradition of examining conscience (1 Cor. 11:28).

verses.text: Fools mock at guilt offerings, but the upright find favor.
verses.comment: Reference to 'guilt offerings' alludes to the Old Testament sacrificial system, foreshadowing Christ's perfect sacrifice (Heb. 9:14). Believers participate by drawing near to God with humility and sacramental confession (John 20:22-23).

verses.text: The heart knows its own bitterness, and a stranger cannot share its joy.
verses.comment: The inner life and its secret sorrows and joys are personal. This highlights the importance of individual conscience, which the Lord alone perfectly understands (1 Sam. 16:7).

verses.text: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, but the tent of the upright will flourish.
verses.comment: Earthly establishments rooted in evil fail, while the righteous, even with little, find growth. This foreshadows Christ's teaching of the humble being exalted (Luke 14:11).

verses.text: There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way to death.
verses.comment: Human wisdom apart from divine revelation leads to destruction. The need to follow God's revealed path, not private judgment, is strongly emphasized here.

verses.text: Even in laughter the heart may ache, and the end of joy may be grief.
verses.comment: Worldly joys are fleeting, but godly hope redeems sorrow. The spiritual life contains both suffering and consolation (2 Cor. 4:16-18).

verses.text: The backslider in heart will be filled with the fruit of his ways, and a good man will be satisfied from above.
verses.comment: This speaks of the consequences of spiritual infidelity or faithfulness. The depth of interior conversion connects to Christian doctrine about the grace given from above.

verses.text: The simple believes every word, but the prudent looks well to his steps.
verses.comment: Discerning spirits and teachings is necessary in the life of faith, avoiding both gullibility and cynicism. Sober discernment is a virtue esteemed throughout Christian history.

verses.text: A wise man fears and departs from evil, but a fool rushes ahead and is reckless.
verses.comment: Wisdom produces humility and caution, turning from sin. This is fulfilled in the Church's call to continual conversion and repentance.

verses.text: A quick-tempered man acts foolishly, and a crafty man is hated.
verses.comment: Both impetuous anger and hidden cunning are against the peace of Christ. Self-mastery is a fruit of the Spirit (Gal. 5:23).

verses.text: The simple inherit folly, but the prudent are crowned with knowledge.
verses.comment: The imagery of being 'crowned' alludes both to earthly wisdom and ultimately to the reward God gives for persevering faith and practical discernment (2 Tim. 4:8).

verses.text: The evil bow down before the good, and the wicked at the gates of the righteous.
verses.comment: Those who oppose God are ultimately brought low before the righteous, foreshadowing judgment and the triumph promised to the saints (Dan. 7:27).

verses.text: The poor is disliked even by his neighbor, but the rich has many friends.
verses.comment: This observation of human nature urges love of neighbor as Christ commands (Luke 10:27), prioritizing mercy over mere worldly esteem.

verses.text: He who despises his neighbor sins, but blessed is he who shows kindness to the poor.
verses.comment: Care for the poor is repeatedly affirmed as a sign of righteousness. Mercy reflects God’s own heart and is inseparable from faithful discipleship.

verses.text: Do they not go astray who devise evil? But steadfast love and faithfulness belong to those who plan what is good.
verses.comment: To 'plan what is good' evokes the virtue of intentionality and charity. 'Steadfast love and faithfulness' are key characteristics of God and those conformed to Him.

verses.text: In all hard work there is profit, but mere talk leads only to poverty.
verses.comment: Diligence, not idle words, advances God’s kingdom in practical and spiritual matters (Col. 3:23).

verses.text: The crown of the wise is their riches, but the folly of fools brings folly.
verses.comment: While wisdom brings honor and reward, folly self-perpetuates. Note the spiritual sense: true riches come from wisdom, not merely material gain.

verses.text: A truthful witness saves lives, but one who utters lies is deceitful.
verses.comment: Bearing true witness is salvific (see John 14:6—Christ as the truth). The parallel between Christ’s testimony and mission is clear here.

verses.text: In the fear of the Lord one has strong confidence, and his children will have a place of refuge.
verses.comment: Reverence for God provides security for oneself and one’s household, reminiscent of household salvation in Acts 16:31.

verses.text: The fear of the Lord is a fountain of life, turning people away from the snares of death.
verses.comment: Fear of the Lord is not servile dread, but awe, drawing us to the grace that saves and sanctifies—a theme woven throughout Scripture.

verses.text: In a multitude of people is a king’s glory, but without people a prince is ruined.
verses.comment: The importance of a united people for leadership echoes the spiritual unity and universality of God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Whoever is slow to anger has great understanding, but he who is quick-tempered exalts folly.
verses.comment: Patience is highly valued, reflecting the virtue of meekness, which Christ modeled and blesses (Matt. 5:5); it is necessary for Christian maturity.

verses.text: A tranquil heart gives life to the flesh, but envy rots the bones.
verses.comment: Inner peace flows from contentment in God. Envy, on the other hand, is spiritually corrosive—seen even in the motives of those who opposed Christ (Matt. 27:18).

verses.text: Whoever oppresses the poor insults his Maker, but he who is generous to the needy honors Him.
verses.comment: Care for the poor is directly connected to honoring God. This anticipates Christ’s teaching that what we do for the least we do for Him.

verses.text: The wicked is brought down by his evil, but the righteous has a refuge in his death.
verses.comment: Ultimate hope for the righteous extends even beyond death—pointing toward the promise of eternal life.

verses.text: Wisdom rests in the heart of one who has understanding, but what is in the heart of fools is made known.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s quiet fruit in the faithful contrasts with folly’s exposure. Jesus also teaches that the heart reveals one’s true character.

verses.text: Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a reproach to any people.
verses.comment: Moral living brings blessings not only to individuals but also societies; foundational for biblical ethics and good governance.

verses.text: The king’s favor is toward a servant who acts wisely, but his wrath falls on one who brings shame.
verses.comment: Rulers reward faithful service, prefiguring how Christ—the King—will reward his faithful in the end (Matt. 25:34).
